doc.repnme: Lending for microenterprises - a review of the World Bank's portfolio
doc.abstracts: Almost all direct World Bank's support for microenterprises is delivered through loans aimed at reducing poverty. A review of the microenterprise programs shows that although they involve only very small amounts, the effort by the Bank's staff to make them work has been enormous. This large up-front effort will pay off only if these small initiatives are understood as pilot programs from which to draw lessons for future programs that can reach large numbers of people. Thus, they should be monitored carefully and ineffective approaches quickly discarded. This Note reviews the design of the Bank's microenterprise loans and describes lessons learned. The review raised four key design questions: 1) Is the strategy of promoting and supporting microenterprise development a sound approach to poverty reduction generally and to employment creation among the poor specifically? 2) Are these components packaged correctly for the Bank to roll microenterprise support programs into poverty reduction operations? 3) Are the institutional arrangements used in these operations well-suited to achieving the objectives? 4) Are the terms and conditions of credit provision in these components in line with international best practice in micro-credit delivery? The Note concludes that the financial support for microenterprises in Bank projects is limited, and suggests options for growing the portfolio.
